author: , Record-Courier
title: Ice blamed for multiple crashes on Kent bridge Wednesday night
text:
Ice blamed for multiple crashes on Kent bridge Wednesday night Jeff Saunders Ravenna Record-Courier Kent safety forces were kept busy for about 90 minutes because of crashes involving nearly a dozen vehicles on the Fairchild Avenue bridge Wednesday night.
Police Lt. Mike Lewis said Thursday that dispatch logs showed as many as 11 vehicles involved in crashes that began at about 6:50 p.m., with police remaining on scene until about 8:20 p.m.
Lewis said there were two requests for ambulances and seven tow trucks were called. Lewis said, however, that he did not have any information about injuries or whether anyone was transported to a hospital.
Due to a shift change since Wednesday night, information was not available Thursday from the Kent Fire Department.
Lewis said it appears that the bridge "iced over pretty badly," causing vehicles to lose control. He said a city salt truck was called to salt the bridge.
"We would just remind people that the bridges ice over more quickly than do the roadways and to exercise caution," said Lewis.
Reporter Jeff Saunders can be reached at jsaunders@recordpub.com.

author: SchoolTube Community
title: The Fascinating World of Marine Life: Exploring the Depths of Our Oceans | SchoolTube
text: The Fascinating World of Marine Life: Exploring the Depths of Our Oceans The ocean, a vast and mysterious realm, covers over 70% of our planet‚Äôs surface and holds a staggering diversity of life. From the tiniest plankton to the majestic whales, the marine world is a captivating tapestry of wonder and complexity. In this blog post, we‚Äôll embark on a journey to explore the fascinating creatures that inhabit our oceans, delve into the ecological balance of these underwater ecosystems, and discuss the importance of conservation efforts. A World of Wonders: Discovering Marine Life The ocean is home to a mind-boggling array of species, each with its unique adaptations and ecological role. From the coral reefs teeming with vibrant fish to the deep-sea trenches inhabited by bizarre creatures, the marine world is a treasure trove of biodiversity. Fish: The Abundant Inhabitants Fish are the most abundant vertebrates on Earth, with over 30,000 known species. They come in all shapes, sizes, and colors, adapted to a wide range of habitats. Some fish, like the clownfish, live in symbiotic relationships with anemones, while others, like the tuna, are powerful predators that roam the open ocean. Marine Mammals: Giants of the Sea Marine mammals, such as whales, dolphins, seals, and sea lions, are highly intelligent and social creatures. Whales, in particular, are awe-inspiring giants that can grow to enormous sizes. These majestic creatures play a crucial role in maintaining the health of ocean ecosystems. Invertebrates: The Unsung Heroes Invertebrates, which include animals without backbones like jellyfish, corals, crabs, and starfish, make up the majority of marine life. These creatures are essential for the functioning of marine ecosystems, from filtering water to providing food for other animals. The Interconnectedness of Marine Ecosystems Marine ecosystems are interconnected and rely on a delicate balance to thrive. The food chain, for example, is a complex network of organisms that depend on each other for survival. Plankton, the microscopic organisms at the base of the food chain, are consumed by larger animals, which are in turn consumed by even larger predators. Coral Reefs: Biodiversity Hotspots Coral reefs are among the most diverse ecosystems on Earth, providing habitat for a vast array of marine life. These underwater cities are essential for the health of oceans, as they protect coastlines from erosion, provide food and income for coastal communities, and contribute to the global carbon cycle. Conservation Efforts: Protecting Our Oceans Human activities, such as pollution, overfishing, and climate change, are posing significant threats to marine ecosystems. It‚Äôs crucial to take action to protect our oceans and the life they support. Reducing Pollution Pollution from land-based sources, such as plastic waste and agricultural runoff, is contaminating oceans and harming marine life. We can reduce pollution by reducing our consumption of plastic, properly disposing of waste, and promoting sustainable agricultural practices. Sustainable Fishing Practices Overfishing is depleting fish stocks and disrupting marine ecosystems. Sustainable fishing practices, such as setting catch limits and using fishing gear that minimizes bycatch, are essential for ensuring the long-term health of fisheries. Addressing Climate Change Climate change is causing ocean acidification, warming waters, and sea level rise, which are having devastating impacts on marine life. We can mitigate climate change by reducing our carbon footprint and supporting efforts to transition to renewable energy sources. Conclusion The marine world is a fascinating and complex ecosystem that is essential for the health of our planet. By understanding the interconnectedness of marine life and the threats they face, we can take action to protect our oceans and ensure that future generations can enjoy the wonders of this incredible realm.

author: Newsfile
title: Former NFL standout Rob Sims and Pro Football Hall of Fame Member Calvin Johnson Jr. Launch Locker Room Insurance to Empower Agents and Elevate the Industry | dailytimesleader.com | Serving West Point & Clay County Since 1867
text:
Los Angeles, California--(Newsfile Corp. - December 28, 2023) - Locker Room Insurance is a forward-thinking insurance brokerage co-founded by 2021 Pro Football Hall of Fame inductee Calvin Johnson Jr. and Rob Sims, his former NFL teammate, along with experienced business executive and licensed insurance agent Craig Freeman. Together, they're on a mission to elevate the insurance industry and reach underserved markets through Locker Room Insurance.
Johnson Jr. , known for his Hall of Fame football career with the Detroit Lions, has been deeply engaged in community service since childhood, in part because he is the grandchild of a Baptist minister. His dedication led him to establish the Calvin Johnson Jr. Foundation , which has made a difference for nearly 13 years.
"The feeling you get from serving people is contagious. It feels great knowing I'm serving my neighbors and providing for families," Johnson Jr. said.
Sims , a nine-year NFL veteran who also played with the Lions, shared a similar sentiment. "We're big on finding solutions that benefit other people. It fills us with excitement to empower those without similar opportunities, enabling them to secure their family's financial future and enhance the community."
Locker Room Insurance
To view an enhanced version of this graphic, please visit:
https://images.newsfilecorp.com/files/8798/191320_bd8138025409e9b3_001full.jpg
Freeman, a mission-driven executive known for his broad business acumen and servant leadership style, is equally excited about the program and its impact on the community.
"A quarter of the population doesn't have any type of insurance," Freeman observed. "We want to be able to help. Rob and Calvin have a lot of people they love to help in various ways, but they can't take all of them to the NFL. They might also not be able to help them with other capital-intensive ventures. With insurance, they'll help many agents change their lives and their families' futures through a low barrier entrance, low capital insurance model."
To get an in-person look at how they operate, apply for an opportunity to attend the Locker Room Insurance launch party in the Detroit area later this year, where they will hosting a NFL Playoff watch party as well as providing a business overview for prospective agents. Apply to attend here .
About Locker Room Insurance:
Locker Room Insurance is a forward-thinking insurance brokerage co-founded by 2021 Pro Football Hall of Fame inductee Calvin Johnson Jr. and Rob Sims, his NFL teammate, along with experienced business executive and licensed agent Craig Freeman. Together, they're on a mission to elevate the insurance industry and reach underserved markets through Locker Room Insurance.
Media Contact:
Company contact full name: Craig Freeman and Robyn Sims
Company contact email: press@lockerroominsurance.com
Contact Phone: 248-8253287

author: VNExplorer
title: Cocoa prices soar ahead of Easter as `impact of climate...
text:
READ MORE: The price of some Easter eggs has risen by 50 per cent in the UK Wet heatwaves and drought in West Africa have severely harmed cocoa crops With Easter fast approaching, you might have already begun to notice that Easter eggs are more expensive this year.
But this isn‚Äôt just due to inflation, as scientists say climate change is a key reason your chocolate is costing more.
According to researchers from the Energy and Climate Intelligence Unit (ECIU), a combination of wet heatwaves and drought have battered this year‚Äôs cocoa harvest.
Combined with a strong El Ni√±o year, this has pushed up the price of some Easter eggs by more than 50 per cent according to Which? data.
Ben Clarke, an expert on extreme weather from Imperial College London, said: ‚Äò[Climate change] fuels more extreme conditions, devastates harvests, and makes food costs higher for all.‚Äô
Some Easter eggs in the UK are now up to 50 per cent more expensive than last year, and experts say that climate change is to blame (file photo)
READ MORE: The real cost of climate change: Global warming could cost the world up to $24 TRILLION over the next 36 years, scientists warn As the choc-heavy holiday of Easter approaches, the prices of some Easter eggs might come as quite a shock.
Some retail prices for the treats are now more than 50 per cent higher than in previous years.
The Maltesers Truffles Luxury Easter Egg now costs ¬£13 ‚Äì a 62.5 per cent increase from last year.
Likewise, a Ferrero Rocher Golden Easter Egg will now set you back a whopping ¬£15 ‚Äì 50 per cent more than in 2023.
Not only are prices getting higher each year, but consumers are also getting less more their money.
Brands such as Cadbury, Galaxy, Mars, Twix, KitKat, Smarties, Yorkie, and Terrys have all shrunk the size of the nation‚Äôs favourite Easter eggs.
As ‚Äòshrinkflation‚Äô hits, the large Mars milk chocolate egg is down from 252g to 201g ‚Äì a reduction of 20 per cent ‚Äì yet the price has remained the same at ¬£3.
Meanwhile, the Twix milk chocolate Easter egg is down from 246g to 200g and the Galaxy Minstrels Easter Egg has been cut from 234g to 192g.
This price surge has been driven by extreme weather conditions in Ghana and the Ivory Coast, according to the new study.
In 2023, the UK imported 58,000 tonnes of cocoa worth ¬£127 million ($162m) from these two countries alone.
However, last year both countries experienced abnormally intense rains and extremely high temperatures.
In West Africa, where most of the world‚Äôs cocoa grows, total rainfall in December was more than double the 30-year average.
In wet conditions, cocoa trees are blighted by a fungal infection called black pod disease which causes the cocoa beans to rot on the tree.
To make matters worse, these wet conditions were then followed by an extremely hot drought.
The price of chocolate has risen, leading to many producers either raising prices or shrinking the product to cut costs
Shrinking Easter Eggs BEFORE AFTER 2023 2024 Mars milk chocolate large Easter egg 252g 201g ¬£3.00 ¬£3.00 Twix milk chocolate Easter egg 246g 200g ¬£3.00 ¬£3.00 Galaxy Minstrels Easter egg 234g 192g ¬£3.00 ¬£3.00
Cadbury Mini Eggs Large Family Chocolate Bag 296g 270g ¬£3.50 ¬£3.50 Cadbury Dairy Milk Fruit and Nut Ultimate Chocolate Egg 532g 400g ¬£10.00 ¬£10.00
KitKat Chunky Milk Chocolate Large Easter Egg 230g 190g ¬£3.50 ¬£3.50 Smarties Orange Easter Egg Large 226g 188g ¬£3.00 ¬£3.00 Yorkie Milk Chocolate Large Easter Egg 242g 196g ¬£3.50 ¬£3.50
Lindt Mini Eggs Canister 177g 155g ¬£4.00 ¬£5.00 Terry‚Äôs Chocolate Orange Egg & Mini Eggs 230g 200g ¬£3.06 ¬£3.19 Source: Average prices from Which? In both Ghana and Ivory Coast, temperatures smashed historical records, climbing above 40¬∞C (104¬∞F).
The extreme heat has led to drought conditions which have persisted since February, drastically reducing crop yields and pushing up prices.
The price of raw cocoa has more than trebled in the last 12 months and more than doubled in the last three months alone.
Currently, the cost of cocoa has reached over ¬£6,700 ($8,500) per tonne, according to Markets Insider, up from ¬£2,030 ($2,600) per tonne this time last year.
Normally, producers would purchase cocoa well in advance, insulating consumers from price shocks.
However, the ECIU noted that the impacts of this volatile weather ‚Äòhas fed through to international commodity prices‚Äô.
The ECIU report also warned that this extreme weather is threatening other staple foods imported to the UK, including rice from India, coffee from Vietnam, tea from Kenya, and grapes from South Africa.
The vast majority of the UK‚Äôs chocolate comes from farms in Ghana (pictured) or Ivory Coast where a combination of wet heatwaves and drought have drastically reduced crop yields
READ MORE: Your sweet tooth is about to get more expensive! Cocoa prices are now DOUBLE what they were a year ago as El Nino weather wreaks havoc on global supply Worryingly, scientists say that ongoing human-induced climate change makes extreme weather conditions like this all the more likely.
This year‚Äôs extreme weather was in part fueled by a strong El Ni√±o that has led to warmer weather conditions across the globe.
El Ni√±o is a cyclical natural phenomenon in the tropical eastern Pacific which brings heat to the surface and can add an extra warming effect to the atmosphere and oceans.
However, analysis from the World Weather Attribution Group suggests that climate change makes extreme temperatures 10 times more likely.
The researchers found that, if humanity does not quickly reduce its emissions, West Africa will experience similar heatwaves once every two years.
Mr Clarke says: ‚ÄòEl Nino years often lead to challenges for farmers through changing patterns of weather.
‚ÄòIncreasingly, climate change, driven by fossil fuel use, is multiplying this natural challenge in many regions.‚Äô
Cocoa is especially vulnerable to these kinds of extreme weather challenges since it grows in such a select region.
Cocoa trees only grow in a narrow band of about 20 degrees around the equator.
According to ECIU, 99 per cent of the world‚Äôs cocoa is grown in countries that are the most vulnerable and least well prepared to deal with climate change.
And, while higher prices might be a challenge for consumers, they may pose an even bigger threat to farmers.
Jon Walker, Fairtrade‚Äôs senior advisor for cocoa, says: ‚ÄòWhile high prices may seem like a windfall for farmers, once they eventually filter through to the farmgate, the underlying causes are worrying.
‚ÄòHigher prices offset by lower productivity simply perpetuates the income insecurity that keeps farmers trapped in poverty and threatens the future of cocoa.‚Äô
Mr Walker adds: ‚ÄòIt remains to be seen if supply will bounce back, or whether the current trend will be longer-lasting.‚Äô
Read more
